poem:
### Overcapacity

In fields of steel and wire  
dreams outpace desires—  
threefold they rise,  
untethered horses  
in an overgrown pasture,  
brimming to burst.  
The road flattens, stretches;  
surpluses spill like  
water, aimless to the sea.  
A silent hum  
echoes, unsettled,  
across borders and ledgers,  
seeking a place to belong.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "China’s overcapacity is creating instability at home and abroad | George Magnus China’s astounding technological success in mass-producing quality electric vehicles (EVs) sits alongside a serious flaw in its industrial model: overcapacity. It has the capacity to produce about three times as many units as it can sell at home. The consequences so far have included widespread price cutting, large losses, misallocation of capital, and surging low-cost EV exports leading to trade conflict. The bigger". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
